title: U.S. Stocks Mixed Amid Wave of Bank Earnings Reports; Twitter rose after Elon Musk disclosed offer to take the it private; Dow industrials up
text:
Twitter shares rose 3.6% after Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk—who already holds a more than 9% stake in the social-media firm—disclosed an offer to buy the company outright in a deal valuing it at more than $43 billion. Tesla fell 2.6%.

UnitedHealth shares rose 1.4% after The healthcare and health-insurance giant posted double-digit revenue growth at both its Optum and UnitedHealthcare units.

Wells Fargo shares fell more than 5% in early trading after the bank reported a drop in first-quarter earnings. Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup each rose after reporting results that were better than analysts' forecasts.

Big U.S. banks are expected to suffer from comparisons to bumper profits during the pandemic. Analysts expect first-quarter earnings for S&P 500 banks fell 37% from a year ago, according to FactSet.

Looking ahead, corporate results will be scrutinized for guidance on how companies expect to manage tighter policy from the Federal Reserve, with a series of interest-rate increases expected.

"Investors are trying to figure out if the Fed is on the right course. Can they stick the landing in terms of bringing inflation down without bringing the economy down?" said David Donabedian, chief investment officer at CIBC Private Wealth.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note rose to 2.789% from 2.688% on Wednesday. While wavering in recent days, the yield on the benchmark note earlier this week hit its highest level since January 2019 as investors gear up for rising interest rates. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

The interest rate on the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage hit 5% for the first time in more than a decade, Freddie Mac said Thursday.

In commodity markets, Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, fell 1.5% to $107.09 a barrel. Gold prices declined 0.2%.

Overseas, the Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.4% as gains for travel stocks balanced losses for telecommunication firms. Sweden's Ericsson dropped 5% after reporting earnings that missed expectations in part because it suspended its operations in Russia.

In Asia, stock markets were mostly higher. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.7% and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.2%.

—Corrie Driebusch contributed to this article.

Write to Will Horner at william.horner@wsj.com
